Key Match Events: Alex Hales made a half-century on his first England appearance in more than three years
Harry Brook played a number of eye-catching shots in his 25-ball innings
Ben Duckett swept and reverse-swept to keep the required rate in hand
Alex Hales was dropped in the deep by Shan Masood looking to manufacture a slog-sweep off Qadir
Pre-Game Insights: Alex Hales made a half-century on his first England appearance in more than three years
Phil Salt was brilliantly held at deep square leg and Usman Qadir struck with his second ball to remove Dawid Malan
Ben Duckett swept and reverse-swept - with varying degrees of success - to keep the required rate in hand
Luke Wood was selected as the third left-arm bowler and brought a few mph extra pace to the equation
Luke Wood conceded just 12 runs from his two overs in the powerplay
Post-Match Reflections: Hales only managed one boundary with the field out between the seventh and 14th overs, and on 28 from 22 he was dropped in the deep by Shan Masood looking to manufacture a slog-sweep off Qadir

The target was always in range and, with 52 needed from 36, Brook and Hales suddenly clicked into gear, the latter going from 38 off 32 to 53 off 39 before holing out to cover with only the finishing touches required
Miscellaneous Highlights: Luke Wood made his T20I debut
Alex Hales made his first T20I fifty since July 2018
Mohammad Rizwan equalled Babar's record as the fastest man to 2000 T20I runs
Haider Ali, playing his first T20I in nine months, struggled to get going before holing out off Sam Curran
Shan Masood, on T20I debut at No. 4, top-edged a reverse-sweep to the edge of the ring for 7 off seven balls
